slide.caption: Lupium refugee camp, one of nine such camps on the Thai border with Myanmar border that have houses upwards of 150,000 registered and non-registered refugees, many for a decade of more. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)

Each refugee camp is run by a committee, which makes key decisions and in many cases mediates in disputes. Pictured are some of the leadership of Lupium camp, including Saw Wah Htee (centre), the leader. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
The largest camp has nearly 50,000 registered and unregistered residents. They are small, leaf-roofed cities complete with barber shops and other amenities. (PHOTO: Ben Parker/IRIN)
A wide variety of food and other goods are available for sale in small shops throughout the camps. (PHOTO: Ben Parker/IRIN)

The residents are totally dependent on food and other goods provided by the Thai Burma Border Consortium (TBBC) of 11 non-governmental organizations. They provide bamboo and other materials to repair camp houses. The Thai government does not permit them to build permanent structures. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
A young camp resident strings leaves to make roofing for her family’s house. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
A stack of leaf roofing ready to be tied in place. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
A new roof is placed on a camp dwelling. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)

With the help of TBBC programme Community Agriculture and Nutrition (CAN) project, residents have been growing their own crops and experimenting with different vegetable varieties. Many of the crops are consumed by boarding school students who have been sent to Nupo camp in search of a better education. (PHOTO: Ben Parker/IRIN)
A Nupo refugee camp youth tends one of the gardens.
A camp resident in Nupo repairs his house while watching over his young one. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
Young Burmese refugees at Nupo camp pitch in to help their mother in rehabilitating their house. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
Members of the NGO American Refugee Committee (ARC) at Umpium Camp provide guidance regarding health issues and gender-based violence. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)

Myint Aye, chairwomen of the Sexual and Gender Based Violence Committee in Mae La refugee camp helps ensure that the serious issues of domestic violence are addressed, with the assistance of the Legal Assistance Centre (an International Rescue Committee /UNHCR project) by the Thai courts or, if less serious by internal mediation within the camp. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)

The TBBC provided material in 2008 for the weaving of men’s sorangs as well as six looms. It helps general employment for the loom operators, those who prepare the yarn for the looms and the administrative staff. (PHOTO: Ben Parker/IRIN)
A Nupo camp resident registers for TBBC assistance. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)

The American Refugee Committee (ARC) provides midwife advanced training to several residents of Umpium camp. There is a high turn-over of midwives as many are now resettling in third countries. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)

Because of poor sanitation, there is a high incidence of diarrhea. Here at the Aide Medicale Internationale (AMI) clinic in Umpium, a mother recovers with her daughter beside her. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
One of the students at the dormitory in Nupo camp, in which dozens of children are sent across the border from Myanmar so their children can get a better education. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
Young girls praying before dinner. They are staying at a hostel in Nupo camp without their parents in order to get a better education. (PHOTO: Ben Parker/IRIN)

A medical check-up conducted by the Organization for International Migration (IOM) at a hospital in Mae Sot. Since 2004 until the end of 2008, more than 43,000 refugees resettled from Thai border camps to 11 plus countries. IOM handles the medical check-ups, cultural orientation and flight arrangements. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
Burmese refugees selected for resettlement await their medical clearance outside a hospital in Mae Sot. (PHOTO: Brennon Jones/IRIN)
As part of the IOM orientation sessions, refugees who are about to get resettled get a look at the high-caloric food they will be encountering in their new countries.

Not only the physically fit are chosen for resettlement: U Nyi suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTDS), his 53-year-old wife, Khin Htwe has been diagnosed with chronic asthma and their 13 year old child, Ye’ Naing Aung, has birth defects that have left him physically deformed and mentally retarded. They are soon to be resettled in the United States. (PHOTO: Ben Parker/IRIN)

At Umpium camp, residents crowd around IOM buses saying their last goodbyes to refugees beginning their long journeys for resettlement in distant countries. Some 13,000 Burmese refugees will be resettled in 2009.
